DOC.HEAD: Campeau Trying to Reassure Lenders
DOC.TEXT: Campeau Corp., struggling under a multibillion-dollar debt, says it hopes to reassure lenders who finance shipments to its department stores that the company's long-term fiscal health is sound. ``We respect the obligations of those with whom we do business to make financial decisions that they deem to be in their own best interests. We remain hopeful that we will be able to resolve this situation favorably, well in advance of spring merchandise deliveries,'' Carol Sanger, Campeau's vice president of corporate communications in Cincinnati. Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., owned by the Toronto-based Campeau, revealed last week that they are trying to restructure $7 billion in debt and may need to seek U.S. Bankruptcy Court protection from creditors while reorganizing their finances. Campeau Corp. assumed more than $8 billion in debt when it bought Cincinnati-based Federated in May 1988. Officials of CIT Group-Factoring, the New York retail lending company and subsidiary of Manufacturers Hanover Corp., expressed concern about the retailers' statements that they could run out of cash by the end of January, endangering payments due suppliers in February and beyond. ``Until the people who sit in the ivory tower in Toronto make some decisions and let people know what's going on, we are reserving a decision about future shipments,'' Francis X. Basile, president and chief executive, said Monday. ``Hopefully, they will do something positive to allow us to continue to support their companies.'' Last week, Heller Financial, a major lender in Chicago, cut off credit on shipments to Campeau stores after the retailers' disclosure last Wednesday. The moves could halt early delivery of spring merchandise to Federated and Allied store divisions, including the Cincinnati-based Lazarus, Burdine's of Miami and Bloomingdale's of New York. It is not known how many clients represented by Heller and CIT still plan to ship spring merchandise to the stores. CIT and Heller are ``factoring'' companies _ those that extend credit to retailers and collect suppliers' bills from retailers _ and have significant influence in the apparel industry. Factoring companies buy manufacturers' products and assume the risks that those bills will be paid by retailers. Without credit from a factoring company, suppliers assume full risk for payment on their shipments. Federated and Allied told the Securities and Exchange Commission that store revenues and loans will give them enough cash until mid-March. But money could run out by late January if suppliers demand quicker payment on bills and lenders cut off money, officials said. ``January 10 is the magical date,'' Basile said. Payments for merchandise shipments are made on the 10th day of a month. Basile said Campeau's disclosure leads him to conclude the company can meet payments due Jan. 10, but that payments due Feb. 10 could be in danger if the company runs out of cash.
